<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_irq_get_controller:
```c
static struct metal_irq_controller *metal_irq_get_controller(int irq)
{
	struct metal_list *node;
	struct metal_irq_controller *cntr;

	metal_list_for_each(&irq_cntrs, node) {
		int irq_base, irq_end;

		cntr = (struct metal_irq_controller *)
		       metal_container_of(node, struct metal_irq_controller,
					  node);
		irq_base = cntr->irq_base;
		irq_end = irq_base + cntr->irq_num;
		if (irq >= irq_base && irq < irq_end) {
			return cntr;
		}
	}
	return NULL;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function metal_irq_get_controller:
static void _metal_irq_set_enable(int irq, unsigned int state)
{
	struct metal_irq_controller *cntr;

	cntr = metal_irq_get_controller(irq);
	if (cntr == NULL) {
		return;
	}
	cntr->irq_set_enable(cntr, irq, state);
}
...
int metal_irq_register(int irq,
		       metal_irq_handler irq_handler,
		       void *arg)
{
	struct metal_irq_controller *cntr;
	struct metal_irq *irq_data;

	cntr = metal_irq_get_controller(irq);
	if (cntr == NULL) {
		return -EINVAL;
	}
	if (cntr->irq_register != NULL) {
		return cntr->irq_register(cntr, irq, irq_handler, arg);
	}
	if (cntr->irqs == NULL) {
		return -EINVAL;
	}
	irq_data = &cntr->irqs[irq - cntr->irq_base];
	irq_data->hd = irq_handler;
	irq_data->arg = arg;
	return 0;
}
...
void metal_irq_enable(unsigned int vector)
{
	_metal_irq_set_enable((int)vector, METAL_IRQ_ENABLE);
}
...
void metal_irq_disable(unsigned int vector)
{
	_metal_irq_set_enable((int)vector, METAL_IRQ_DISABLE);
}
...

explanation:
I selected all code fragments that perform function calls which could participate in direct or indirect recursion: the definition of metal_irq_get_controller itself, functions that call it ( _metal_irq_set_enable and metal_irq_register ), and the thin wrappers (metal_irq_enable / metal_irq_disable). The potentially recursive sites of interest are the calls to metal_irq_get_controller and the indirect calls through controller function pointers (cntr->irq_set_enable and cntr->irq_register) since those callbacks could call back into the IRQ API, forming indirect recursion.

Other code fragments need not be investigated for Rule 17.2 because they contain only local computations, pointer arithmetic, assignments, or macro-based list traversal without additional function calls (e.g. computing irq_base/irq_end, assigning irq_data->hd/arg, the metal_list_for_each/metal_container_of usage as shown). Those lines do not introduce further function-call edges that could create self- or mutual-recursion, so they are not relevant to Rule 17.2 analysis based on the provided code. (If the definitions of the controller callbacks or of the used macros are available, they should be inspected separately because they are the only places that could introduce indirect recursion back into the listed functions.)
